claim: If video recordings of lectures are provided, nothing in particular happens to class attendance.

supporting.text: Studies in educational research have shown that providing video recordings of lectures does not significantly impact in-person attendance rates.

attacks.text: Studies in educational research have shown that providing video recordings of lectures does not significantly impact in-person attendance rates.
Some studies indicate that providing lecture recordings can lead to a decline in attendance, especially among students who prioritize convenience over in-person engagement.
The decline in attendance due to lecture recordings is often context-dependent and more pronounced in large introductory courses compared to smaller, discussion-based classes.
Lecture recordings may disproportionately affect attendance in courses with less interactive or engaging teaching styles, where students perceive less value in attending in person.
Even in less interactive courses, many students still attend in person due to social motivations, structured schedules, or the belief that physical presence aids learning.

supporting.text: Students often attend lectures for reasons beyond content access, such as interaction with instructors or peers, which video recordings do not replace.

attacks.text: Students often attend lectures for reasons beyond content access, such as interaction with instructors or peers, which video recordings do not replace.
Studies show that when lectures are recorded, attendance drops significantly, as students prioritize convenience over in-person interaction.
The drop in attendance may be temporary; students often return to in-person lectures once they realize the value of real-time interaction and engagement.
Many students report that recorded lectures reduce their motivation to attend in-person, as they can watch at their own pace and skip sections.
Instructors who integrate active learning and participation grades see no significant drop in attendance, even with recorded lectures available.

supporting.text: Institutions that provide lecture recordings report no substantial decline in attendance, as many students still prefer live participation for engagement.

attacks.text: Institutions that provide lecture recordings report no substantial decline in attendance, as many students still prefer live participation for engagement.
Studies show that lecture recordings can lead to reduced attendance, as students prioritize flexibility over live engagement.
The preference for live engagement varies by subject and teaching style, making generalizations unreliable.
Institutions may underreport attendance declines to maintain enrollment numbers or avoid policy changes.
Independent audits and student surveys often corroborate institutional reports on attendance trends.

supporting.text: Empirical data from universities indicate that attendance patterns remain stable when lecture recordings are made available as a supplementary resource.

attacks.text: Empirical data from universities indicate that attendance patterns remain stable when lecture recordings are made available as a supplementary resource.
Some studies show that attendance declines when recordings are available, as students prefer flexibility over in-person attendance.
The decline in attendance is often offset by increased engagement with recorded content, leading to no net negative impact on learning outcomes.
Attendance stability may depend on course difficulty; in easier courses, recordings lead to lower attendance, while in harder courses, attendance remains stable.
Even in easier courses, students who skip lectures but watch recordings often perform similarly, suggesting attendance is not a critical factor.

supporting.text: The convenience of video recordings does not eliminate the value of real-time Q&A and discussions, which sustain in-person attendance.

attacks.text: The convenience of video recordings does not eliminate the value of real-time Q&A and discussions, which sustain in-person attendance.
Many students prioritize convenience over interaction, leading to lower attendance even if Q&A is valuable.
Studies show that students who attend live lectures perform better in exams, reinforcing the importance of in-person interaction.
Hybrid models show that recorded lectures often replace in-person attendance entirely for a significant portion of students.
Institutions with mandatory attendance policies see no drop in attendance despite offering recordings, proving structure matters more than format.
